references: We answer this question in the affirmative by proposing AFedPG, an algorithm that asynchronously updates the global policy using policy gradients from federated agents. The key components of the proposed AFedPG include a delay-adaptive lookahead technique, which addresses the inconsistent arrival times of updates during the training process. The improvement of AFedPG over other approaches is summarized in Table 1. Here, the global time is measured by the number of global updates Ã—\times time complexity in each iteration. In terms of sample complexity, the federated learning technique brings a linear speedup with respect to the number of agents Nğ‘N. As for the global time, AFedPG improves from ğ’ªâ€‹(tmaxNâ€‹Ïµâˆ’2.5)ğ’ªsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘superscriptitalic-Ïµ2.5\mathcal{O}(\frac{t_{\max}}{N}{\epsilon}^{-2.5}) to ğ’ªâ€‹(tÂ¯â€‹Ïµâˆ’2.5)ğ’ªÂ¯ğ‘¡superscriptitalic-Ïµ2.5\mathcal{O}(\bar{t}{\epsilon}^{-2.5}), where tÂ¯â‰”1/âˆ‘i=1N1tiâ‰”Â¯ğ‘¡1superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘1subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–\bar{t}\coloneqq 1/\sum_{i=1}^{N}\frac{1}{t_{i}} is a harmonic average and always smaller than tmax/Nsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘t_{\max}/N, and tisubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–t_{i} denotes the time complexity in each iteration at agent iğ‘–i.

Linear speedup in sample complexity: As shown in Table 1, our federated method improves the sample complexity in each agent from ğ’ªâ€‹(Ïµâˆ’2.5)ğ’ªsuperscriptitalic-Ïµ2.5\mathcal{O}({\epsilon}^{-2.5}) (single agent PG) to ğ’ªâ€‹(Ïµâˆ’2.5N)ğ’ªsuperscriptitalic-Ïµ2.5ğ‘\mathcal{O}(\frac{{\epsilon}^{-2.5}}{N}), where Nğ‘N is the number of federated agents. This represents the linear speedup with respect to the number of agents Nğ‘N.

Speedup of sample complexity: First, to verify the improvement of sample complexity in the first row of Table 1, we evaluate the speedup effects of the number of federated agents Nğ‘N. In Figure 4, with different numbers of agents, we test the convergence performances of AFedPG (N=2,4,8ğ‘248N=2,4,8) and the single agent PG (N=1ğ‘1N=1). The x-axis is the number of samples collected by each agent on average, and the y-axis is the reward. In all three MuJoCo tasks, AFedPG beats the single-agent PG: AFedPG converges faster, has lower variances, and achieves higher final rewards when more agents are involved in collecting trajectories and estimating policy gradients. These results confirm the advantage of AFedPG in terms of sample complexity.

Improvement of global time complexity:
Second, to verify the improvement of global time complexity in the second row of Table 1, we compared the time consumption in the asynchronous and synchronous settings. In Figure 5, we set N=4,8ğ‘48N=4,~{}8 and fix the number of samples collected by all agents. Here, tmaxsubscriptğ‘¡t_{\max} is about 444 times more than tminsubscriptğ‘¡t_{\min}. The numbers of total samples (trajectories) are 8Ã—1038superscript1038\times 10^{3}, 16Ã—10316superscript10316\times 10^{3}, and 8Ã—1048superscript1048\times 10^{4} for the Swimmer-v4 task, Hopper-v4 task, and Humanoid-v4 task individually when N=8ğ‘8N=8. When N=4ğ‘4N=4, the numbers are halved. In all three environments, AFedPG has much lower time consumption compared to the synchronous FedPG, confirming the enhancement in terms of time complexity.

references: Environment: To validate the effectiveness of our approach via experiments, we consider three popular MuJoCo environments (Swimmer-v4, Hopper-v4, and Humanoid-v4) (Todorov etÂ al., 2012) with the MIT License. Both the state and action spaces are continuous. Environmental details are described in Table 2 and the MuJoCo tasks are visualized in Figure 3.

references: Implementation: Policies are parameterized by fully connected multi-layer perceptions (MLPs) with settings listed in Table 3. We follow the practical settings in stable-baselines3 (Raffin etÂ al., 2021) to update models with generalized advantage estimation (GAE) (0.950.950.95) (Schulman etÂ al., 2018) in our implementation. We use PyTorch (Paszke etÂ al., 2019) to implement deep neural networks (DNNs). All tasks are trained on NVIDIA A100 GPUs with 404040 GB of memory.
